Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A community member casually mentioned wanting advice whenever the imam has free time.
Story:
I sat at my desk, headset pressing into my ear, as another call connected. “Hello, this is Amir from BrightNet Services. How can I help you today?” The customer’s voice was sharp, firing off technical questions about our new internet package—questions my script only half-covered. I tried to sound confident, flipping through the FAQ, but my answers felt hollow. My supervisor expected me to handle every objection smoothly, to never let a customer sense uncertainty. Each call left me more tense, my mind racing with what I should have said.

Between calls, my phone buzzed with a message from Farid, a community member from the mosque. “Imam, I’d love to talk when you have a moment. Need some advice.” I knew what was expected of me as an imam: to listen, to guide, to be present and compassionate. But the calls kept coming, and my break was only ten minutes. I stared at the blinking cursor on my screen, torn between the demands of my job and the needs of my community. My heart ached with the weight of both roles, unsure how to be enough for either.
